question.content:
The upper-left coordinate on a rectangle is $(-4,4)$, and the upper-right coordinate is $(4,4)$.  The rectangle has an area of $8$ square units.  

**Draw the rectangle on the coordinate plane below.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
Let's draw the two coordinates we know:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3c351a04e0465a21b1aa12c5861d2312c42e19f9)

What is the distance between the two points?

The distance between the points is $\greenD8$ units.  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/35e626c5f725e8e21c4214ab1a49ba6cc6d96b21)

The opposite side of the rectangle will also be $\greenD8$ units.

Perimeter is the sum of all the side lengths.

 If we subtract the $2$ sides we know from the total perimeter, we will know the length of the missing sides.

$20 - \greenD8 - \greenD8 = \purpleD4$

The missing sides have a combined length of $\purpleD4$ units. We can divide to find the length of each side.

$\dfrac{\purpleD{4}}{2} = \blueD2$

Each missing side will be $\blueD2$ units.

Now we can draw the lower-right and lower-left coordinates $\blueD2$ units below the existing coordinates:

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3495b40afe33a2deb4f820d79356ab2165e06746)

question.content:
The upper-left coordinate on a rectangle is $(-5, 6)$, and the upper-right coordinate is $(-2, 6)$.  The rectangle has a perimeter of $16$ units.  

**Draw the rectangle on the coordinate plane below.**

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8c8fdc4364a922f1f32b5a73af03b00ff1331cf3)

Since $A(\greenD{5},\blueD{ 1})$ and $B(\greenD{7}, \blueD{1})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{7}-\greenD{5}&=2\end{align}$  


Side $AB$ had a length of $2$ units.

Side $DC$ is opposite of side $AB$, so it also has a length of $2$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{5},\blueD{ 1})$ and $D(\greenD{5}, \blueD{6})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{6}-\blueD{1}&=5\end{align}$  

Side $AD$ had a length of $5$ units.

Side $BC$ is opposite of side $AD$, so it also has a length of $5$ units

Now we can find the perimeter.

Perimeter is the sum of all the side lengths.

$\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &=  2+2+5+5
\\\\
\phantom{\text{Perimeter}}&= 14
\end{align}$
The perimeter of the rectangle is $14$ units.

question.content:
Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle:
$A(5, 1),$ $B(7,1)$, $C(7, 6)$, and $D(5, 6)$.  

**What is the perimeter of rectangle $ABCD$?**

[[☃ input-number 1]] units

hints.content:
Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c675bb3eecfedd13ee8bb54cfb68db2c93942585)

Since $A(\greenD{-6},\blueD{-4})$ and $B(\greenD{-4}, \blueD{-4})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{-4}-\left(\greenD{-6}\right)&=2\end{align}$  


Side $AB$ had a length of $2$ units.

Side $DC$ is opposite of side $AB$, so it also has a length of $2$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{-6},\blueD{-4})$ and $D(\greenD{-6}, \blueD{-2})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{-2}-\left(\blueD{-4}\right)&=2\end{align}$  

Side $AD$ had a length of $2$ units.

Side $BC$ is opposite of side $AD$, so it also has a length of $2$ units

Now we can find the perimeter.

Perimeter is the sum of all the side lengths.

$\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &=  2+2+2+2
\\\\
\phantom{\text{Perimeter}}&= 8
\end{align}$
The perimeter of the rectangle is $8$ units.

question.content:
Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle:
$A(-6, -4),$ $B(-4,-4)$, $C(-4, -2)$, and $D(-6, -2)$.  

**What is the perimeter of rectangle $ABCD$?**

[[☃ input-number 1]] units

hints.content:
Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f982738bb92c70b9c2690ecb50717b0b1dc0c5cf)

Since $A(\greenD{2},\blueD{-6})$ and $B(\greenD{5}, \blueD{-6})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{5}-\greenD{2}&=3\end{align}$  


Side $AB$ had a length of $3$ units.

Side $DC$ is opposite of side $AB$, so it also has a length of $3$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{2},\blueD{-6})$ and $D(\greenD{2}, \blueD{-2})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{-2}-\left(\blueD{-6}\right)&=4\end{align}$  

Side $AD$ had a length of $4$ units.

Side $BC$ is opposite of side $AD$, so it also has a length of $4$ units

Now we can find the perimeter.

Perimeter is the sum of all the side lengths.

$\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &=  3+3+4+4
\\\\
\phantom{\text{Perimeter}}&= 14
\end{align}$
The perimeter of the rectangle is $14$ units.

question.content:
Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle:
$A(2, -6),$ $B(5, -6)$, $C(5, -2)$, and $D(2, -2)$.  

**What is the perimeter of rectangle $ABCD$?**

[[☃ input-number 1]] units

hints.content:
Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/00ff0fba417c100921b56f8c26f425a5e891aba1)

Since $A(\greenD{2},\blueD{-3})$ and $B(\greenD{4}, \blueD{-3})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{4}-\greenD{2}&=2\end{align}$  


Side $AB$ had a length of $2$ units.

Side $DC$ is opposite of side $AB$, so it also has a length of $2$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{2},\blueD{-3})$ and $D(\greenD{2}, \blueD{5})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{5}-\left(\blueD{-3}\right)&=8\end{align}$  

Side $AD$ had a length of $8$ units.

Side $BC$ is opposite of side $AD$, so it also has a length of $8$ units

Now we can find the perimeter.

Perimeter is the sum of all the side lengths.

$\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &=  2+2+8+8
\\\\
\phantom{\text{Perimeter}}&= 20
\end{align}$
The perimeter of the rectangle is $20$ units.

question.content:
Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle:
$A(2, -3),$ $B(4, -3)$, $C(4, 5)$, and $D(2, 5)$.  

**What is the perimeter of rectangle $ABCD$?**

[[☃ input-number 1]] units

hints.content:
Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/49e72dd18cadccc800f4de306ad191a3627cecb1)

Since $A(\greenD{-2},\blueD{1})$ and $B(\greenD{3}, \blueD{1})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{3}-\left(\greenD{-2}\right)&=5\end{align}$  


Side $AB$ had a length of $5$ units.

Side $DC$ is opposite of side $AB$, so it also has a length of $5$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{-2},\blueD{1})$ and $D(\greenD{-2}, \blueD{4})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{4}-\blueD{1}&=3\end{align}$  

Side $AD$ had a length of $3$ units.

Side $BC$ is opposite of side $AD$, so it also has a length of $3$ units

Now we can find the perimeter.

Perimeter is the sum of all the side lengths.

$\begin{align} \text{Perimeter} &=  5+5+3+3
\\\\
\phantom{\text{Perimeter}}&= 16
\end{align}$
The perimeter of the rectangle is $16$ units.

question.content:
Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle:
$A(-2, 1),$ $B(3, 1)$, $C(3, 4)$, and $D(-2, 4)$.  

**What is the perimeter of rectangle $ABCD$?**

[[☃ input-number 1]] units

hints.content:
Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/26e897d6622e120c0653765dc207cff83586d6f8)

Since $A(\greenD{2},\blueD{ 0})$ and $B(\greenD{6}, \blueD{0})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{6}-\greenD{2}&=4\end{align}$  


Side $AB$ had a length of $4$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{2},\blueD{ 0})$ and $D(\greenD{2}, \blueD{7})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{7}-\blueD{0}&=7\end{align}$  

Side $AD$ had a length of $7$ units.

Now we can find the area.


$\begin{align} \text{Area} &=  \text{length} \times \text{width} 
\\\\
\text{Area} &=4\times 7
\\\\
\text{Area} &= 28
\end{align}$
The area of the rectangle is $28$ square units.

question.content:
Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle:
$A(2, 0)$, $B(6, 0)$, $C(6, 7)$, and $D(2, 7)$.  

**What is the area of rectangle $ABCD$?**

[[☃ input-number 1]] square units

hints.content:
Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3b7d4bf06c15ccbad6fc76448b8c1cea7efbfad8)

Since $A(\greenD{-4},\blueD{ -2})$ and $B(\greenD{-2}, \blueD{-2})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{-2}-(\greenD{-4})&=2\end{align}$  


Side $AB$ had a length of $2$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{-4},\blueD{ -2})$ and $D(\greenD{-4}, \blueD{7})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{7}-(\blueD{-2})&=9\end{align}$  

Side $AD$ had a length of $9$ units.

Now we can find the area.


$\begin{align} \text{Area} &=  \text{length} \times \text{width} 
\\\\
\text{Area} &=2\times 9
\\\\
\text{Area} &= 18
\end{align}$
The area of the rectangle is $18$ square units.

Since $A(\greenD{-8},\blueD{ 3})$ and $B(\greenD{-3}, \blueD{3})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{-3}-(\greenD{-8})&=5\end{align}$  


Side $AB$ had a length of $5$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{-8},\blueD{ 3})$ and $D(\greenD{-8}, \blueD{6})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{6}-\blueD{3}&=3\end{align}$  

Side $AD$ had a length of $3$ units.

Now we can find the area.


$\begin{align} \text{Area} &=  \text{length} \times \text{width} 
\\\\
\text{Area} &=5\times 3
\\\\
\text{Area} &= 15
\end{align}$
The area of the rectangle is $15$ square units.

question.content:

Since $A(\greenD{-2},\blueD{ 2})$ and $B(\greenD{6}, \blueD{2})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{6}-(\greenD{-2})&=8\end{align}$  


Side $AB$ had a length of $8$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{-2},\blueD{ 2})$ and $D(\greenD{-2}, \blueD{3})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{3}-\blueD{2}&=1\end{align}$  

Side $AD$ had a length of $1$ units.

Now we can find the area.


$\begin{align} \text{Area} &=  \text{length} \times \text{width} 
\\\\
\text{Area} &=8\times 1
\\\\
\text{Area} &= 8
\end{align}$
The area of the rectangle is $8$ square units.

question.content:
Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle:
$A(-2, 2)$, $B(6, 2)$, $C(6, 3)$, and $D(-2, 3)$.  

**What is the area of rectangle $ABCD$?**

[[☃ input-number 1]] square units

hints.content:
Let's begin by drawing our rectangle.  

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/61f9d48ed56e38bdce44020c81eee33b7c9aea74)

Since $A(\greenD{3},\blueD{ -2})$ and $B(\greenD{6}, \blueD{-2})$ have the same $\blueD{y}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AB$ is the distance between the $\greenD{x}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\greenD{6}-\greenD{3}&=3\end{align}$  


Side $AB$ had a length of $3$ units.

Since $A(\greenD{3},\blueD{ -2})$ and $D(\greenD{3}, \blueD{5})$ have the same $\greenD{x}$-coordinates, they form a horizontal line segment.  Therefore the length of $AD$ is the distance between the $\blueD{y}$-coordinates:



$\qquad \begin{align}\blueD{5}-(\blueD{-2})&=7\end{align}$  

Side $AD$ had a length of $7$ units.

Now we can find the area.


$\begin{align} \text{Area} &=  \text{length} \times \text{width} 
\\\\
\text{Area} &=3\times 7
\\\\
\text{Area} &= 21
\end{align}$
The area of the rectangle is $21$ square units.

question.content:
Rectangle $ABCD$ is graphed in the coordinate plane.  The following are the vertices of the rectangle:
$A(3, -2)$, $B(6, -2)$, $C(6, 5)$, and $D(3, 5)$.  

**What is the area of rectangle $ABCD$?**

[[☃ input-number 1]] square units
